# The [sifah_mush]{.subs}

## Introduction

The [sifah_mush]{.subs} is a [mushtaqq]{.subs} noun.
It is the quintessential [sifah]{.subs} signifying a relatively stable and unchanging meaning.
[حَسَن]{.ar} [handsome, good]{.trans} is an example of a [sifah_mush]{.subs}.

The [sifah_mush]{.subs} is called such because it shares some characteristics with the [ism_fail]{.subs}.
The [ism_fail]{.subs} is the closest of the [mushtaqq]{.subs} nouns to the verb.
We saw in chapter\ (ref) that it can govern in a verb-like manner and even be used in place of a verb.

The [sifah_mush]{.subs}, although not as close to the verb as the [ism_fail]{.subs},
can also govern in a manner which is similar (but not quite exactly the same) as the governing of the [ism_fail]{.subs}.
In this chapter, we will explore its significance and its ability to govern in a verb-like manner.

## The forms of the [sifah_mush]{.subs}

The [sifah_mush]{.subs} comes in various forms.
We will list the most common of them^[The following list is taken mostly from [النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/285ff]:

## The [sifah_mush]{.subs} as the governor of a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun

Just like the [ism_fail]{.subs}, the [sifah_mush]{.subs} will,
by default,
govern a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 161]
Consider the following examples:

(@) [مررت بامرأة حسنة]{.ar}
    [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 161]{.citex}  
    [I passed by a handsome woman.]{.trans}  
    ([حسنة]{.ar} has a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun implicated as [هي]{.ar}.)

(@) [مررت برجلين حسنين]{.ar}
    [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 161]{.citex}  
    [I passed by two handsome men.]{.trans}  
    ([حسنين]{.ar} has a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [هما]{.ar}.)

## The [sifah_mush]{.subs} as the governor of a [sababi]{.subs} [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}

[[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/303--304](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/1529#p1)]

Similar to the [ism_fail]{.subs}
the [sifah_mush]{.subs} can govern a [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}.
So we can say:

(@) [مررت برجل حسن وجهه]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1077]{.citex}  

(@) [مررت برجلين حسن أبواهما]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1077]{.citex}  

(@) [مررت برجال حسن آباؤهم]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1077]{.citex}  

(@) [الرجال كريمة أمهاتهم]{.ar}

(@) [رأيت الرجالَ الكريمةَ أمهاتهم]{.ar}


Also similar to the [ism_fail]{.subs},
when [sifah_mush]{.subs}'s [faa3il]{.subs} is a broken plural
(as in example () above [آباؤهم]{.ar}),
then the [sifah_mush]{.subs} is permitted, and preferred, to also be a broken plural.^[[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/453–454](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/1679#p1); [fawzan_sharh_qatr 248](https://shamela.ws/book/2135/248#p1); [[شرح قطر الندى وبل الصدى]{.ar} 288](https://shamela.ws/book/6970/263)]

So we can say:

(@) [مررت برجال حسانٍ آباؤهم]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1077]{.citex}  

(@) [هؤلاءِ زملاءُ كرامٌ آباؤهم]{.ar}
    [[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/453](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/1679#p1)]{.citex}

But if the [faa3il]{.subs} of the [sifah_mush]{.subs} is a sound plural,
then it is preferred that the [sifah_mush]{.subs} remain singular.
Examples:

(@) [هؤلاء زملاءُ كريم والدوهم]{.ar}
    [[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/454](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/1680#p1)]{.citex}

(@) [هؤلاء زميلات كريمة والداتهن]{.ar}
    [[[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 3/454](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/1680#p1)]{.citex}


By the way, when the [sifah_mush]{.subs} is a [na3t]{.subs},
then instead of using a [sababi]{.subs} na3t
(as in examples () above),
we can use a sentence [na3t]{.subs}.
So instead of saying
[مررت برجل حسنٍ وجهه]{.ar},
we can say:

(@) [مررت برجل حسنٌ وجهه]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1076]{.citex}  

Now the [na3t]{.subs} is the sentence
[حسنٌ وجهُه]{.ar}
[handsome, his face is]{.trans}.
[حسن]{.ar} in this sentence is a fronted [xabar]{.subs}.

#### The [sifah_mush]{.subs} cannot govern a non-[sababi]{.subs} [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} {.unnumbered}

In section\ (ref) above,
we saw that an [ism_fail]{.subs} can govern a
non-[sababi]{.subs} [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}.
Unlike the [ism_fail]{.subs}
the [sifah_mush]{.subs} can only govern a [sababi]{.subs} [zaahir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}.
So we cannot say:

(@) [x]{.subs} [مررت برجل حَسَنٍ عمرٌو في داره]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1075]{.citex}  
    [I passed a man [whom] [#eamr]{.trn2} was handsome in his house.]{.trans}  

## The [sifah_mush]{.subs} in a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}

Like the [ism_fail]{.subs},
the [sifah_mush]{.subs} forms a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} with its governee.
In section\ (ref),
we learned that
the [ism_fail]{.subs} forms a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} between the [ism_fail]{.subs} and its semantic [mafulb]{.subs}.
The [sifah_mush]{.subs} is typically from an intransitive verb.
so it will not have a [mafulb]{.subs}.
Instead, it
forms a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} in two ways:

 i. A [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} between the [sifah_mush]{.subs} and its semantic _[faa3il]{.subs}_.
ii. A [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} between the [sifah_mush]{.subs} and its [tamyiz]{.subs}.

### [#lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} between the [sifah_mush]{.subs} and its semantic [faa3il]{.subs}

The [sifah_mush]{.subs} can form a
[lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} between the [sifah_mush]{.subs} and its semantic [faa3il]{.subs}.
It does this by first transforming its [faa3il]{.subs} into a _[mafulb]{.subs}-like_ governee.
Wil will explaing this process below:

Consider the sentence:

(@) [مررت برجل حسنٍ وجهُه]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1077]{.citex}

In this sentence,
the [sifah_mush]{.subs} has a definite [sababi]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}
[وجهه]{.ar}.
This sentence is transformed in the following manner^[[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1080]:

#### First step of the transformation {.unnumbered}

Firstly, the base noun pronoun
[ه]{.ar}
in
[وجهه]{.ar}
is transferred to being a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun of the [sifah_mush]{.subs}
[حسن]{.ar}.

#### Second step of the transformation {.unnumbered}

Secondly,
[وجه]{.ar},
with its base noun pronoun
[ه]{.ar}
eliminated, is made into
[الوجه]{.ar}
to keep it definite
(to match [وجهه]{.ar} which was also definite).

Now that
the [sifah_mush]{.subs}
[حسن]{.ar}
already has a [faa3il]{.subs}
(its [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun [هو]{.ar}),
the noun
[الوجه]{.ar}
cannot be its [faa3il]{.subs}.
So it is made into what we will call a
_[mafulb]{.subs}-like_ governee.
So it is put into the [astate]{.subs} thus:
[الْوَجْهَ]{.ar}.

We call [الْوَجْهَ]{.ar} a [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee, and not a true [mafulb]{.subs} because, in meaning, it is still the [faa3il]{.subs} of the [sifah_mush]{.subs}
[حسن]{.ar}.
The [sifah_mush]{.subs}
[حسن]{.ar}
is derived from an intransitive verb
[حَسُنَ]{.ar}
which does not take a [mafulb]{.subs}.

With this transformation,
the sentence becomes:

(@) [مررت برجل حسنٍ الوجهَ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1080]{.citex}

It is important to note that this transformation affects only the syntax of the sentence, but not its meaning.
The [sifah_mush]{.subs}
[حسن]{.ar}
is still describing a quality of [الوجه]{.ar},
not [رجل]{.ar}.

But now that [الوجه]{.ar} is not syntactically the [faa3il]{.subs} of the [sifah_mush]{.subs},
the [sifah_mush]{.subs} match its syntactic referent [رجل]{.ar}
in gender and number,
not its semantic [faa3il]{.subs}
[الوجه]{.ar}.
So we will say:

(@) [مررت برجلين حسنين الوجهين]{.ar}

(@) [مررت برجالٍ حسانٍ الوجوهَ]{.ar}

(@) [مررت بمرأة حسنة الوجهَ]{.ar}

(@) [مررت بمرأتين حسنتين الوجهين]{.ar}

Remember, that it
[الوجه]{.ar}
were syntactically the [faa3il]{.subs},
then we would have said instead:

(@) [مررت برجلين حسنين وجهاهما]{.ar}

(@) [مررت بمرأة حَسَنٍ وجهُهَا]{.ar}

etc.

The transformation that we have described above works exactly the same for definite [sifah_mush]{.subs}s.
So we will say:

(@) [مررت بالرجل الحسن الوجهَ]{.ar}

(@) [جاءت المرأتان الحسنتان الوجهين]{.ar}

etc.

#### Final step of the transformation {.unnumbered}

A sentence with a [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee,
like in example ()
[مررت برجل حسنٍ الوجهَ]{.ar}
above,
while grammatically correct, is rarely used in practice.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 166]
The main purpose of the [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee is that it is used as a intermediate step for the final step of the transformation:
and that is into a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 167]
This is done by converting the [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee into a syntactic [mudafil]{.subs}.

### With an indefinite [astate]{.subs} governee

Remember from section\ (ref),
that the [tamyiz]{.subs} is a [astate]{.subs} governee that specifies the scope of its governor.
So we can say, for example:

(@) [مررت برجل حسن وجهًا]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1080]{.citex}

(@) [جاءت المرأة الحسنة وجهًا]{.ar}

(@) [الزيدون حسنون وجوها]{.ar}
    [[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 9/241]{.citex}  

The [tamyiz]{.subs} is thus very commonly used with the [sifah_mush]{.subs}.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 167 citing [شرح الرضي على الكافية]{.ar} 3/439]

### The word order of the [sifah_mush]{.subs} and its [astate]{.subs} [governee]{.subs}

Recall from section\ (ref) above that the [astate]{.subs} governee of a [ism_fail]{.subs} is permitted to precede its governing [ism_fail]{.subs} in word order.
So we can say:

(@) [زيد عمرا ضارب]{.ar}
    [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/143]{.citex}

But this is not permitted for the [sifah_mush]{.subs}.^ [[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 1/259; [شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/143]
So we cannot say:

(@) [زَيْدٌ الْوَجْهَ حَسَنٌ]{.ar}
    [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/143]{.citex}

Lets start with [sifah_mush]{.subs}s with their [mafulb]{.subs}-like governees:

* Indefinite [sifah_mush]{.subs}: [حَسَنٌ الْوَجْهَ]{.ar}
* Definite [sifah_mush]{.subs}: [الْحَسَنُ الْوَجْهَ]{.ar}

The
[astate]{.subs} [mafulb]{.subs}-like governees
are converted into [mudafil]{.subs}s in the [istate]{.subs}:

* Indefinite [sifah_mush]{.subs}: [حَسَنُ الْوَجْهِ]{.ar}
* Definite [sifah_mush]{.subs}: [الْحَسَنُ الْوَجْهِ]{.ar}


Here are some examples using this [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}:

(@sifah_mush_marartu_birajulin_hasanil_wajhi) [مررت برجل حسنِ الوجهِ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1078, 1081]{.citex}

(@) [جاء الرجل الحسنُ الوجهِ]{.ar}

Note that, because [الوجه]{.ar} is a [astate]{.subs} governee, and not the [faa3il]{.subs},
of the [sifah_mush]{.subs}, therefore, the [sifah_mush]{.subs} is feminized, dualized, or pluralized to match its referent, not [الوجه]{.ar}.
Examples:

(@) [هند حسنة الوجه]{.ar}
    [[شرح الرضي على الكافية]{.ar} 3/439]{.citex}

(@) [الزيدان حسنا الوجهين]{.ar}
    [[شرح الرضي على الكافية]{.ar} 3/439]{.citex}

(@) [الزيدون حسنو الوجوه]{.ar}
    [[شرح الرضي على الكافية]{.ar} 3/439]{.citex}

## The [sifah_mush]{.subs} with a [tamyiz]{.subs}

Remember from section\ (ref),
that the [tamyiz]{.subs} is a [astate]{.subs} governee that specifies the scope of its governor.
As a verb-like noun,
the [sifah_mush]{.subs}
can govern a [tamyiz]{.subs}.
So we can say, for example:

(@) [مررت برجل حسن وجهًا]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 1080]{.citex}

(@) [جاءت المرأة الحسنة وجهًا]{.ar}

(@) [الزيدون حسنون وجوها]{.ar}
    [[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 9/241]{.citex}  

### [#lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} of the [sifah_mush]{.subs} with a [tamyiz]{.subs}

As with the [sifah_mush]{.subs} that has a [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee,
the [sifah_mush]{.subs} with a [tamyiz]{.subs}
also can also form a
[lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.

So
[حَسَنٌ وَجْهًا]{.ar} will become:

(@) [حسنُ وجهٍ]{.ar}
    [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 171]{.citex}

Again, the [sifah_mush]{.subs} will match its referent in gender and number.
So, for example, we will say:

(@) [هم حسنو وجوه]{.ar}
    [[[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 9/227](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3012)]{.citex}  

Unlike, the [sifah_mush]{.subs} with a [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee,
a [sifah_mush]{.subs} prefixed by [ال]{.ar} with a [tamyiz]{.subs} does not form a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}
This is because a definite [mudaf]{.subs} 
with an indefinite [mudafil]{.subs} is fundamentally inconsistent with an [idaafah]{.subs} construction.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 169]{.citex}
So
[الْحَسَنُ وَجْهًا]{.ar}, 
however, does not
form a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}
to become:

(@) [x]{.subs} [الحسنُ وجهٍ]{.ar}
    [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 169]{.citex}

Finally,
whereas the [sifah_mush]{.subs} with its [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee
(e.g. [حَسَنُ الْوَجْهَ]{.ar})
is pretty much only used as an intermediate step to form a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs},
such is not the case for 
the
[sifah_mush]{.subs} with a [tamyiz]{.subs}.
The
[sifah_mush]{.subs} with a [tamyiz]{.subs}
can be used, as is, without converting it into a
[lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 167 citing [شرح الرضي على الكافية]{.ar} 3/439]

So we can say:

(@) [زيد حسنُ وجهٍ]{.ar}

## The word order of the [sifah_mush]{.subs} and its [astate]{.subs} governee

Recall from section\ (ref) above that the [astate]{.subs} governee of a [ism_fail]{.subs} is permitted to precede its governing [ism_fail]{.subs} in word order.
So we can say:

(@) [زيد عمرا ضارب]{.ar}
    [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/143]{.citex}

But this is not permitted for the [sifah_mush]{.subs}.^ [[شرح كتاب سيبويه للسيرافي]{.ar} 1/259; [شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/143]
So we cannot say:

(@) [x]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ الْوَجْهَ حَسَنٌ]{.ar}
    [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/143]{.citex}

Nor is the [tamyiz]{.subs} allowed to precede its governing [sifah_mush]{.subs}
(see section\ (ref)).
So we cannot say:

(@) [x]{.subs} [زيد وَجها حسن]{.ar}
    [[[المقتضب للمبرد]{.ar} 4/164](https://shamela.ws/book/6965/1178)]{.citex}  


## Uncommon constructions of the [sifah_mush]{.subs}

There are some constructions of the [sifah_mush]{.subs},
that are uncommonly found.
Some are disagreed upon with regard to their grammatical correctness.
Some grammarians allow some of them unconditionally, others by poetic license only, while others would disallow them.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 162--170]{.citex}

We list these constructions here for compleness:

#### Governing a [faa3il]{.subs} {.unnumbered}

(@) [حَسَنٌ الْوَجْهُ]{.ar} [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 162]{.citex}

(@) [الْحَسَنُ الْوَجْهُ]{.ar} [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 162]{.citex}

(@) [حَسَنٌ وَجْهٌ]{.ar} [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 163]{.citex}

(@) [الْحَسَنُ وَجْهٌ]{.ar} [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 163]{.citex}

#### Governing a [astate]{.subs} governee {.unnumbered}

(@) [حَسَنٌ وَجْهَهُ]{.ar} [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 166]{.citex}

(@) [الْحَسَنُ وَجْهَهُ]{.ar} [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 166]{.citex}

#### In a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} {.unnumbered}

(@) [حَسَنُ وَجْهِهِ]{.ar} [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 169]{.citex}

When the [sifah_mush]{.subs} is defined by [أل]{.ar}
and the semantic [faa3il]{.subs} is not defined by [أل]{.ar},
then a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}
is disallowed.^[[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 166]{.citex}
For example:

(@) [x]{.subs} [الْحَسَنُ وَجْهِهِ]{.ar} [[الضمير المستتر لسعود بن عبيد الله الصاعدي]{.ar} 169]{.citex}

## [#lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} to an [idaafah]{.subs}

It is possible for the [faa3il]{.subs} of a [sifah_mush]{.subs} to itself be in an [idaafah]{.subs}.
For example:

(@) [زَيْدٌ حَسَنٌ وَجْهُ أَبِيهِ]{.ar}

(@) [رَأَيْتُ الرَّجُلَ الطَّوِيلَةَ لِحْيَةُ أَبِيهِ]{.ar}

[#lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}s can, in general, be formed from such constructions
after, of course, first transforming the [faa3il]{.subs}s into [astate]{.subs} governees.

But
when the [sifah_mush]{.subs} is defined by [أل]{.ar},
then a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} is only permitted,
if the [mudafil]{.subs} of semantic [faa3il]{.subs} also is defined by [أل]{.ar}.^[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/145--146]
Compare this with section\ (ref) for the [ism_fail]{.subs}.
Examples:

(@) [v]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ حَسَنُ وَجْهِ الْأَبِ]{.ar}

(@) [v]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ حَسَنُ وَجْهِ أَبٍ]{.ar}

(@) [v]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ حَسَنُ وَجْهِ أَبِيهِ]{.ar}

(@) [v]{.subs} [رَأَيْتُ الرَّجُلَ الطَّوِيلَ لِحْيَةِ الْأَبِ]{.ar}

(@) [x]{.subs} [رَأَيْتُ الرَّجُلَ الطَّوِيلَ لِحْيَةِ أَبٍ]{.ar}

(@) [x]{.subs} [رَأَيْتُ الرَّجُلَ الطَّوِيلَ لِحْيَةِ أَبِيهِ]{.ar}

## Significance of the [sifah_mush]{.subs}

The [sifah_mush]{.subs} is typically derived from a stative verb.
A stative verb is one which,
rather than describing any process or action,
signifies that its [faa3il]{.subs} is in a particular state.
Futhermore, its [faa3il]{.subs} does not do any actual work or action that causes him to be in the state described by the [sifah_mush]{.subs}.


### Permanence of the meaning of the [sifah_mush]{.subs}

Some [sifah_mush]{.subs}s have a very permanent meaning. For example:

|[sifah_mush]{.subs} | meaning |
|:---|:-----|
|[أَخْضَر]{.ar}  |[green]{.trans} |
|[أَعْرَج]{.ar}  |[lame]{.trans} |
|[شَرِيف]{.ar}  |[noble, highborn]{.trans} |
|[زَنِيم]{.ar}  |[ignoble, baseborn]{.trans} |

Others are fairly permanent but can change gradually.
For example:

|[sifah_mush]{.subs} | meaning |
|:---|:-----|
|[جَمِيل]{.ar}|[beautiful]{.trans}|
|[قَبِيح]{.ar}|[ugly]{.trans}|

Others can change fairly quickly.
For example

|[sifah_mush]{.subs} | meaning |
|:---|:-----|
|[جَوْعَان]{.ar} |[hungry]{.trans} |
|[فَرِح]{.ar}   |[joyous]{.trans} |
|[تَعِب]{.ar}   |[tired]{.trans} |

### Transitivity of the verb from which the [ism_fail]{.subs} is derived

The [sifah_mush]{.subs} is typically derived from intransitive verbs.
Rarely, we find a [sifah_mush]{.subs} which is derived from a transitive verb.
For example:

|[sifah_mush]{.subs} | meaning |
|:---|:-----|
|[ثَكْلَان]{.ar}|[bereft (of child)|


### [#sifah_mush]{.subs}s whose meaning aligns with the [maful]{.subs}

Most of the time, the [sifah_mush]{.subs} aligns in meaning with the [faa3il]{.subs} of the verb from which it is derived.
For example,
[حَسَن]{.ar} [handsome]{.trans} aligns in meaning with the [faa3il]{.subs} of the verb [حَسُنَ]{.ar} [to be handsome]{.trans}.
Occasionally, however,
the [sifah_mush]{.subs} aligns in meaning with the [maful]{.subs} of its verb.
Examples:

|[sifah_mush]{.subs}|meaning | verb |
|:--|:----|:----|
|[حَمِيد]{.ar}| [praiseworthy]{.trans}             | [حَمِدَ]{.ar} [to praise (s.o.)]{.trans}|
|[ذَمِيم]{.ar}| [blameworthy]{.trans}              | [ذَمَّ]{.ar}  [to blame (s.o.)]{.trans}|
|[مَنِيع]{.ar}| [inaccessible, impregnable]{.trans}| [مَنَعَ]{.ar} [to prevent (s.o., s.th.)]{.trans}|

## The [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}

Whereas [sifah_mush]{.subs} are typically derived from stative verbs,
[ism_fail]{.subs}s are derived from both intransitive verbs
(like [قَائِم]{.ar} from [قَامَ]{.ar} [to stand]{.trans}),
and transitive verbs
(like [ضَارِب]{.ar} from [ضَرَبَ]{.ar} [to beat]{.trans}).
Furthermore, when a verb has a stative meaning,
then,
as we learned in section\ (ref)
its [ism_fail]{.subs} is often not in common usage.
Instead, a [sifah_mush]{.subs} will often exist for the stative verb and the [sifah_mush]{.subs} will be generally used instead.
For example,
the [ism_fail]{.subs} 
[كَارِم]{.ar}
of the stative verb
[كَرُمَ]{.ar} [to be noble, generous]{.trans}
is rarely used.
Instead, the [sifah_mush]{.subs}
[كَرِيم]{.ar} [noble, generous]{.trans}
will generally be used instead.
But, as we also learned,
[كَارِم]{.ar}
could be used when temporary meaning is intended.

The above is the general rule for [ism_fail]{.subs}s of stative verbs.
However, there are some stative verbs, for which the [ism_fail]{.subs} is commonly used,
but only after it crosses over to become a [sifah_mush]{.subs}.
As with
the [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[substantive]{.subs}
there are two categories of [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}s:

 i. The lexical [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
ii. The ad\ hoc [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}

### The lexical [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}

The lexical [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
is one which is commonly used with its [sifah_mush]{.subs} meaning.
It will typically have its own entry in a dictionary.
Examples are:

|verb|meaning|[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}|
|:--|:-----|:-----|
|[طَهُرَ]{.ar} |[to be clean]{.trans}          |[طَاهِر]{.ar} [clean]{.trans}|
|[ضَمَرَ]{.ar} |[to be lean]{.trans}           |[ضَامِر]{.ar} [lean]{.trans}|
|[صَلُحَ]{.ar} |[to be righteous]{.trans}      |[صَالِح]{.ar} [righteous]{.trans}|
|[نَعُمَ]{.ar} |[to be soft]{.trans}           |[نَاعِم]{.ar} [soft]{.trans}|
|[بَسُلَ]{.ar} |[to be courageous]{.trans}     |[بَاسِل]{.ar} [courageous]{.trans}|

Sometimes, a true [sifah_mush]{.subs}
with a similar meaning,
can co-exist with
the lexical [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs},
For example
[طَهِير]{.ar} [clean]{.trans}.

Sometimes,
lexical [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
occurs for verbs which are not purely stative.
In fact, it can even occur for transitive verbs.
Here are some examples:

|verb|meaning|[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}|
|:--|:-----|:-----|
|[عَدَلَ]{.ar} |[to act justly]{.trans}           |[عَادِل]{.ar} [just]{.trans}|
|[رَبِحَ]{.ar} |[to gain a profit]{.trans}        |[رَابِح]{.ar} [profitable]{.trans}|
|[ظَلَمَ]{.ar} |[to wrong (s.o.)]{.trans}         |[ظَالِم]{.ar} [unjust, tyrannical]{.trans}|
|[رَحِمَ]{.ar} |[to have mercy (on s.o.)]{.trans} |[رَاحِم]{.ar} [merciful]{.trans}|
|[قَطَعَ]{.ar} |[to cut (s.th.)]{.trans}          |[قَاطِع]{.ar} [sharp, incisive]{.trans}|

Occasionally, the meaning of the [ism_fail]{.subs} can change considerably when it crosses over to a [sifah_mush]{.subs}.
For example:

|verb|meaning|[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}|
|:--|:-----|:-----|
|[كَتَمَ]{.ar} |[to conceal (s.th)]{.trans}  |[كَاتِم]{.ar} [concealed]{.trans}|
|[دَفَقَ]{.ar} |[to pour (s.th.)]{.trans}    |[دَافِق]{.ar} [poured forth]{.trans}|

In the above examples, we can see that the
lexical [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}s
actually have the meaning of the [ism_maful]{.subs}s.
So [سِرٌّ كَاتِمٌ]{.ar} 
[Lane's Lexicon [»دفق«]{.ar}]{.citex}
is [a concealed secret]{.trans},
and [مَاءٌ دَافِقٌ]{.ar}
[Lane's Lexicon [»دفق«]{.ar}]{.citex}
is [water that is poured forth]{.trans}.^[See also [[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/69/21) for [سورة الحاقة]{.ar} 69:21 [فَهُوَ فِی عِیشَةٍ رَّاضِیَةٍ]{.ar}]
But the [ism_fail]{.subs} can still be used with its original meaning.
For example:

(@) [وَلَوْ كَانَ مُحَمَّدٌ صلى الله عليه وسلم **كَاتِمًا** شَيْئًا مِمَّا أُنْزِلَ عَلَيْهِ لَكَتَمَ هَذِهِ الآيَةَ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :177b](https://sunnah.com/muslim:177b)]{.citex}  
    And if [#muHammad]{.trn2} were to conceal anything from what was revealed to him, he would have concealed this [ayah]{.subs}.

When an [ism_fail]{.subs} crosses over to a [sifah_mush]{.subs},
then it will govern in the manner of a [sifah_mush]{.subs}.
So, it can govern a [faa3il]{.subs},
and the [faa3il]{.subs} is transformed into a [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee,
which is then used in a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
For example:

(@) [طَاهِرُ الْقَلْبِ]{.ar}
    [[شرح التصريح على التوضيح]{.ar} 2/41]{.citex}  
    [clean of heart]{.trans}  
    (The transformation is [طَاهِرٌ قَلْبُهُ]{.ar} [rarr]{.subs} [طَاهِرٌ الْقَلْبَ]{.ar} [rarr]{.subs} [طَاهِرُ الْقَلْبِ]{.ar}.)

(@) [ضَامِرُ الْكَشْحِ]{.ar}
    [[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 10/298]{.citex}  
    [lean of flank]{.trans}  
    (The transformation is
    [ضَامِرٌ كَشْحُهُ]{.ar}
    [rarr]{.subs}
    [ضَامِرٌ الْكَشْحَ]{.ar}
    [rarr]{.subs}
    [ضَامِرُ الْكَشْحِ]{.ar}.)

The process above is normal and straightforward when it comes to
[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}s
that are derived from intransitive verbs.
But if a
[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
is derived from a transitive verb, then there is more care required when using it in a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
For example, consider the following two
[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}s
that are derived from transitive verbs:

|verb|meaning|[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}|
|:--|:-----|:-----|
|[ظَلَمَ]{.ar} |[to wrong (s.o.)]{.trans}         |[ظَالِم]{.ar} [unjust, tyrannical]{.trans}|
|[رَحِمَ]{.ar} |[to have mercy (on s.o.)]{.trans} |[رَاحِم]{.ar} [merciful]{.trans}|

Now let's say that we wish to use the
[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
[رَاحِم]{.ar}
in a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
Then, it is preferred that the actual [mafulb]{.subs} of the [ism_fail]{.subs} not be mentioned.
So, for example, we can say

(@) [زَيْدٌ رَاحِمُ الْقَلْبِ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is merciful of heart.]{.trans}

But we shouldn't say:

(@) [x]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ رَاحِمُ الْقَلْبِ النَّاسَ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd is merciful of heart to the people.]{.trans}

Sometimes, the meaning of the syntactic [mudafil]{.subs} can cause ambiguity.
For example if we say:

(@) [زَيْدٌ رَاحِمُ الْأَبْنَاءِ]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/104](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/920#p1)]{.citex}  

then there are two routes to end up with this construction:

 i. [رَاحِم]{.ar} is a [ism_fail]{.subs} and [الأَبْنَاء]{.ar} is its [mafulb]{.subs}.
    The original sentence is:

    (@) [زَيْدٌ رَاحِمٌ الْأَبْنَاءَ]{.ar}  
        [Zayd is/will be having mercy on the sons.]{.trans}

ii. [رَاحِم]{.ar} is a
    [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
    and [الأَبْنَاء]{.ar} is its semantic [faa3il]{.subs}.
    The original sentence is:

    (@) [زَيْدٌ رَاحِمٌ أَبْنَاؤُهُ]{.ar}  
        [Zayd is merciful of sons.]{.trans}  
        i.e. [Zayd has merciful sons.]{.trans}  

    This sentence gets transformed according to the transformation of [sifah_mush]{.subs}s.
    Even though [رَاحِم]{.ar} is derived from a transitive verb,
    its governee [أَبْنَاء]{.ar} is treated as a [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee,
    not as a [mafulb]{.subs}.^[[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/104](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/920#p1)]
    So the transformation is
    [زَيْدٌ رَاحِمٌ أَبْنَاؤُهُ]{.ar}
    [rarr]{.subs}
    [زَيْدٌ رَاحِمٌ الْأَبْنَاءَ]{.ar}
    [rarr]{.subs}
    [زَيْدٌ رَاحِمُ الْأَبْنَاءِ]{.ar}.


There is actually a third route as well, where [رَاحِم]{.ar} is an
ad\ hoc [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[substantive]{.subs}.
In this case the meaning would be
[Zayd is the merciful-one of the sons]{.trans}.
However, this meaning is a little less likely and not very relevant to our discussion here.

Coming back to the sentence
[زَيْدٌ رَاحِمُ الْأَبْنَاءِ]{.ar},
there is no problem with using
[رَاحِمُ الْقَلْبِ]{.ar} as a
[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
to mean
[merciful of sons]{.trans}.
But only if context makes it clear that Zayd has merciful sons, not that he is having mercy on the sons.

Similarly,
one can say

(@) [زَيْدٌ ظَالِمُ الْعَبِيدِ]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/104](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/920#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd is unjust of slaves.]{.trans}  

when it is known that
Zayd has unjust slaves.^[[[المساعد على تسهيل الفوائد لابن عقيل]{.ar} 2/222](https://shamela.ws/book/133358/818); see also [[الدر المصون للسمين الحلبي]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/aldur-almasoon/14/39) for [سورة إبراهيم]{.ar} 14:39]



The lexical [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs} is not as common for form\ 1 verbs as the true [sifah_mush]{.subs}.
But for form\ 2+ verbs,
the
[ism_fail]{.subs} crossing over to a [sifah_mush]{.subs}
is the default mechanism to derive a [sifah_mush]{.subs} from the verb.
Examples:

|verb|meaning|[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}|
|:--|:-----|:-----|
|[انْطَلَقَ]{.ar}  |[to be let loose]{.trans} |[مْنْطَلِقُ اللِّسَانِ]{.ar} [fluent of tongue]{.trans} [[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 3/308]{.citex}  |
|[اطْمَأَنَّ]{.ar}  |[to be tranquil]{.trans}  |[مُطْمَئِنُّ الْقَلْبِ]{.ar}  [tranquil of heart]{.trans} [[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 3/308]{.citex}  |
|[اسْتَقَامَ]{.ar} |[to be upright]{.trans}   |[مُسْتَقِيم]{.ar}       [straight]{.trans}         |
|[اعْتَدَلَ]{.ar}  |[to be moderate]{.trans}  |[مُعْتَدِل]{.ar}        [moderate]{.trans}         |

### The ad\ hoc [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}

The ad\ hoc [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
can be created from any [ism_fail]{.subs}, on the fly,
when what is intended by the [ism_fail]{.subs} is a more permanent quality.
So, for example,
the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[قَائِم]{.ar}
can cross over to a [sifah_mush]{.subs} 
if its referent is standing more constantly than the [ism_fail]{.subs} would signify.
Now it can follow the same transformation of
governing a [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee and then into a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.^[[[المساعد على تسهيل الفوائد لابن عقيل]{.ar} 2/222](https://shamela.ws/book/133358/818); [[شرح الأشمونى لألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 2/230](https://shamela.ws/book/11742/757)]
So we can say:

(@) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمُ الْأَبِ]{.ar}
    [[[المساعد على تسهيل الفوائد لابن عقيل]{.ar} 2/222](https://shamela.ws/book/133358/818)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd's father is a stander.]{.trans}  
    (The process of transformation is
    [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ أَبُوهُ]{.ar}
    [rarr]{.subs}
    [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ الْأَبَ]{.ar} 
    [rarr]{.subs}
    [زَيْدٌ قَائِمُ الْأَبِ]{.ar}.)

But we should not use the [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}
[زَيْدٌ قَائِمُ الْأَبِ]{.ar}
with the temporary meaning of the [ism_fail]{.subs}
[Zayd's father is standing]{.trans}.
This is because then
[قَائِم]{.ar}
is not a [sifah_mush]{.subs} and thus cannot govern a [mafulb]{.subs}-like governee.^[[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/140](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/818); [[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar} 4/393](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/2382)]
And it is derived from a transitive verb,
so it cannot govern a true [mafulb]{.subs} either.
So we can't say
(with a temporary meaning):

(@) [x]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ قَائِمُ الْأَبِ غَدًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/140](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/818)]{.citex}
    [Zayd's father will stand tomorrow.]{.trans}
    
We should only say, in this case:

(@) [زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ أَبُوهُ غَدًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/140](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/818)]{.citex}
    [Zayd's father will stand tomorrow.]{.trans}

An
ad\ hoc [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
can be formed from a transitive [ism_fail]{.subs} using the same reasoning.
So we can say:

(@) [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبُ الْأَبِ]{.ar}
    [[[المساعد على تسهيل الفوائد لابن عقيل]{.ar} 2/222--223](https://shamela.ws/book/133358/818)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd's father is a beater.]{.trans}

But one should only use such a construction when context makes it clear that Zayd's father is the beater.
Otherwise the apparent meaning, out of context, is [Zayd is the beater of the father]{.trans}.
By the way, 
we have already learned in section\ (ref) above that
when a 
[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[sifah_mush]{.subs}
is derived from a transitive verb,
then the true [mafulb]{.subs} of the verb should not be used.
So we shouldn't say:

(@) [x]{.subs} [زَيْدٌ ضَارِبُ الْأَبِ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
    [[[المساعد على تسهيل الفوائد لابن عقيل]{.ar} 2/223](https://shamela.ws/book/133358/819#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd's father is a beater of [#eamr]{.trn2}.]{.trans}

## The [substantive]{.subs} that crosses over to a [sifah]{.subs}

It is possible for a
[substantive]{.subs} to cross over to a [sifah]{.subs}.
Sometimes this crossing over is metaphorical,
such that the [substantive]{.subs} is used with an [sifah]{.subs} meaning.
For example:

(@) [مررت برجل أسد]{.ar}  
    [I passed by a lion man]{.trans}  
    ([lion]{.trans} is used metaphorical to mean courageous.)

Othertimes, the [substantive]{.subs} is simply used descriptively.
For example:

(@) [مررت برجل عبد]{.ar}
    [I passed by a slave man]{.trans}

When a [substantive]{.subs} crosses over to a [sifah]{.subs},
then it will govern a [mustatir]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs} pronoun.
This [faa3il]{.subs} can also be an [zaahir]{.subs} [sababi]{.subs} [faa3il]{.subs}.
For example:

(@) [مررت برجل عبد أبوه]{.ar}
    [[[الكشاف للزمخشري]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/kashaf/4/172) for [سورة النساء]{.ar} 4:172]{.citex}

## The lexical [sifah_mush]{.subs}-crossover-to-[substantive]{.subs}

Very often,
a [sifah_mush]{.subs} can cross over to a [substantive]{.subs}.

Here are some examples:

|[sifah_mush]{.subs}-crossover-to-substantive | meaning |
|:----|:-----|
|[صَغِير]{.ar}  |[a baby]{.trans} |
|[كَبِير]{.ar}  |[a elder person]{.trans} |
|[صَغِيرَة]{.ar} |[a minor sin]{.trans} |
|[كَبِيرَة]{.ar} |[a major sin]{.trans} |
|[نَصِيحَة]{.ar} |[an advice]{.trans} |
|[حَسَنَة]{.ar}  |[a good deed]{.trans} |

As with 
[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[substantive]{.subs}s
when an [sifah]{.subs} crosses over to a [substantive]{.subs}, it loses its genderizability.
For example, the feminine [sifah_mush]{.subs} [حَسَنَة]{.ar}  [good]{.trans}
crosses over to a [substantive]{.subs} to mean [a good deed]{.trans}.
Let's use it in a sentence:

(@) [ٱلصِّيَامُ حَسَنَةٌ.]{.ar}  
    [Fasting is a good deed.]{.trans}

The [mubtada]{.subs} in this sentence is the masculine noun [ٱَلصِّيَام]{.ar} [fasting]{.trans}.
And the [xabar]{.subs} is the feminine noun [حَسَنَة]{.ar} [a good deed]{.trans}.
Note that the [xabar]{.subs} does not match the [mubtada]{.subs} in gender.
This is because it lost its genderizability since it is no longer acting as an [sifah_mush]{.subs} 
[good]{.trans}, but rather as the [substantive]{.subs} [a good deed]{.trans}.

What if we have the sentence:

(@) [ٱَلصَّدَقَةُ حَسَنَةٌ.]{.ar}  

The feminine gender of the [mubtada]{.subs} 
[ٱَلصَّدَقَة.]{.ar} 
[charity]{.trans}
now matches the gender of the [xabar]{.subs}
[حَسَنَة]{.ar}.
So now, technically, the [xabar]{.subs} could be the [sifah_mush]{.subs}, meaning [good]{.trans}.
So the sentence could mean
[Charity is good.]{.trans}

Or the [xabar]{.subs} could be the [substantive]{.subs} meaning [a good deed]{.trans}.
Then the sentence would mean
[Charity is a good deed.]{.trans}.

Context would be needed to tell us which meaning is intended.


Frequently,
when
a [sifah_mush]{.subs} can cross over to a [substantive]{.subs},
then it uses a different plural from the original [sifah_mush]{.subs}.
For example,
[كَبِيرَة]{.ar}
as a [sifah_mush]{.subs} can use the broken plural [كِبَار]{.ar}.
So we can say:

(@) [الْجَوَارِي كِبَارٌ]{.ar}
    [The girls are big.]{.trans}  
    ([كَبِيرات]{.ar} could also have been used.)


But when
[كَبِيرَة]{.ar}
crosses over to a [substantive]{.subs},
then it will use the plural [كَبَائِر]{.ar}.
For example:

(@) [هَذِهِ الْأَفْعَالُ كَبَائِرُ]{.ar}  
    [These acts are major sins.]{.trans}

#### The [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[substantive]{.subs} on the pattern [فَعِيل]{.ar} {.unnumbered}

There is a special category of
lexical [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[substantive]{.subs}s
and that is on the pattern [فَعِيل]{.ar},
when it has the meaning of the [ism_maful]{.subs}.
Examples are:

|[sifah_mush]{.subs}-crossover-to-substantive | meaning | verb | definition |
|:----|:-----|:--|:----|
|[قَتِيل]{.ar}  |[a killed person]{.trans}  |[قَتَلَ]{.ar} | [to kill (s.o.)]{.trans} |
|[جَرِيح]{.ar}  |[a wounded person]{.trans} |[جَرَحَ]{.ar} | [to wound (s.o.)]{.trans} |
|[أَجِير]{.ar}  |[a hired person]{.trans}   |[أَجَرَ]{.ar} | [to hire (s.o.)]{.trans} |

These 
[ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[substantive]{.subs}s are used under the following general guidelines:

* They can be used as a [na3t]{.subs} (by crossing back over to a [sifah]{.subs} as in section\ (ref) above)).

* When with an (explicit or implicit) noun as its referent has been previously mentioned, then only the masculine noun is used, even for feminine referents.

* When used without an (explicit or implicit)  noun as its referent, then the feminine noun (with [ة]{.ar}) may be used for a feminine referent.

Here are some examples:

(@) [مررت بامرأة جريح]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 4/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/1101#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I passed by a wounded-person woman.]{.trans}  

(@) [مررت برجل جريح أبوه]{.ar}
    [[[المساعد على تسهيل الفوائد لابن عقيل]{.ar} 2/209](https://shamela.ws/book/133358/805#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I passed by a man whose father was a wounded-person.]{.trans}  

(@) [رَأَيْتُ قَتِيلًا وَقَتِيلَةً]{.ar}  
    [I saw a male killed person and a female killed person.]{.trans}  

Not all [sifah_mush]{.subs}s with the meaning of the [ism_maful]{.subs} cross over (lexically) to [substantive]{.subs}s.
Some remain as [sifah_mush]{.subs}s and then are feminized as usual.
For example:

(@) [رَجُلٌ حَمِيدٌ وَامْرأَةٌ حَمِيدَةٌ]{.ar}  
    [a praiseworthy man and a praiseworthy woman]{.trans}

(@) [رَجُلٌ ذَمِيمٌ وَامْرأَةٌ ذَمِيمَةٌ]{.ar}  
    [a blameworthy man and a blameworthy woman]{.trans}

(@) [حِصْنٌ مَنِيعٌ وَقَلْعَةٌ مَنِيعَةٌ]{.ar}  
    [an impregnable fort and an impregnable citadel]{.trans}

Another example od
lexical [ism_fail]{.subs}-crossover-to-[substantive]{.subs}s
that is on the pattern [فَعِيل]{.ar} is:

|[sifah_mush]{.subs}-crossover-to-substantive | meaning | verb | definition |
|:----|:-----|:--|:----|
|[رَهِينَة]{.ar} |[a pledged-item]{.trans}   |[رَهَنَ]{.ar} | [to pledge (s.th.)]{.trans} |

In this case, the [substantive]{.subs} has a [ة]{.ar} and can be used for both masculine and feminine referents.
For example:

(@) [كُلُّ غُلاَمٍ رَهِينَةٌ بِعَقِيقَتِهِ]{.ar}
    [[[سنن أبي داود]{.ar} :2837](https://sunnah.com/abudawud:2837)]{.citex}  
    [Every boy is a pledge by his [#eaqIqah]{.trn2}]{.trans}

The masculine [رَهِين]{.ar} can also be used but it will generally retain its [sifah]{.subs} sense.^[Lane's Lexicon entry [رَهْن]{.ar}]

## Definiteness of a [sifah_mush]{.subs} in a [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} 

We learned in section\ (ref)
that the [mudaf]{.subs} in a
[lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} is not made definite by a definite [mudafil]{.subs}.
We saw this in example (@sifah_mush_marartu_birajulin_hasanil_wajhi) [مررت برجل حسنِ الوجهِ]{.ar},
where
[حَسَن]{.ar}
in the [lafzi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs} remains indefinite
even though it is a [mudaf]{.subs} to a definite [mudafil]{.subs}
[الْوَجْهِ]{.ar}.
Therefore,
the indefinite
[حَسَن]{.ar}
is a [na3t]{.subs} to the indefinite [manut]{.subs}
[رَجُل]{.ar}.

If the [manut]{.subs} is definite,
then the [sifah_mush]{.subs} [mudaf]{.subs} is prefixed by [ال]{.ar}.

(@) [مررت بالرجل الحسنِ الوجهِ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 4/116](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/1480)]{.citex}

(@) [مررتُ بزيدٍ الحسنِ الوجهِ، وهندٍ الجائلةِ الوِشاح]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/132](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/582)]{.citex}

This rule of a [sifah_mush]{.subs} not becoming definite because of a definite [mudafil]{.subs}
is followed more strictly than for the [ism_fail]{.subs}.^[[[دراسات في النحو للزعبلاوي]{.ar} 495](https://shamela.ws/book/2120/495)]
In the case of an [ism_fail]{.subs},
we saw in section\ (ref) that it can cross over to a [substantive]{.subs} in an ad\ hoc manner.
When this happens, then it it becomes definite when it is a [mudaf]{.subs} to a definite [mudafil]{.subs}
(section\ (ref)).

But the [sifah_mush]{.subs}, when it is a [mudaf]{.subs} to its semantic [faa3il]{.subs},
cannot be understood as a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
That is 
[حَسَنُ الْوَجْهِ]{.ar}
[handsome of face]{.trans}
can only be understood to mean that the face is handsome,
never [the face's handsome-one]{.trans}.
So we cannot, in general, say:

(@) [x]{.subs} [مررت بزيد حسن الوجه]{.ar}
    [[[دراسات في النحو للزعبلاوي]{.ar} 496](https://shamela.ws/book/2120/496) citing [الجامي]{.ar}]{.citex}  

We would have to say [مررتُ بزيدٍ الحسنِ الوجهِ]{.ar} instead, as in example () above.

All this notwithstanding,
some grammarians allow,
on occasion,
a [sifah_mush]{.subs},
when a [mudaf]{.subs} to its semantic [faa3il]{.subs},
to become definite by a definite [mudafil]{.subs}.
This is by reason of aligning to form of a [ma3nawi]{.subs} [idaafah]{.subs}.
For more discussion on this, see
[[تفسير ابن عثيمين]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/ibn-uthaymeen/40/3) for [سورة غافر]{.ar} 40:3:

(@) [غَافِرِ ٱلذَّنۢبِ وَقَابِلِ ٱلتَّوۡبِ **شَدِیدِ ٱلۡعِقَابِ** ذِی ٱلطَّوۡلِۖ لَاۤ إِلَـٰهَ إِلَّا هُوَۖ إِلَیۡهِ ٱلۡمَصِیرُ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة غافر]{.ar} 40:3](https://quran.com/40/3)]{.citex}  
    [The forgiver of sin, acceptor of repentance, severe in punishment, owner of abundance. There is no deity except Him; to Him is the destination.]{.trans}
